content: As most of us know from our years of military service, the code of conduct stipulates that if captured, one must provide their captor with the following information: Name, rank, date of birth and serial number (SSN). I don't think I would give my captor my full social security number. Too much mischief can be done now with a SSN, and frankly, I would expect the enemy to try to use it to damage me financially while I was under their control if I didn't feed them intelligence. Is this an example, in your opinion, of a rule/norm that made sense at one time, but now should be changed to protect people from exploitation?

content: Believe it or not, most people's first reaction to being captured in wartime is not "What will this do to my credit rating?" Since your name, rank and serial number are on your ID card (required by the Geneva and Hague conventions), your uniform and your dogtags (also required by law), I don't really see how verbally giving them are in any way an additional piece of information for your captors. It might just be a means for you to avoid being shot as a spy impersonating someone else. Please tell me this line of questions is tongue-in-cheek. Sullivan013

content: What I tried to say is, it isn't a 'policy' by the US, it is a requirement of the Geneva and Hague Conventions for all armed combatants of signatory nations. It has nothing to do with the new uniform changes or any such nonsense. The inclusion of velcro was for simple convienience to change from uniform to uniform without sewing anything. The very reason for the name tapes, dogtags, etc. is the Geneva Convention. It's not even a 'military ID'. It's a Geneva Convention ID Card. My retiree card says so, but I admit I haven't seen the latest active duty cards. Now, if you say the US should drop the use of the SSN, I would agree, but there would have to be a unique number for each member with a card nevertheless. Adding an additional unique number might just cause enough confusion to allow even MORE identity theft than there is now, but that's a chance to be taken. Sullivan013
